questions.question: In the OSI reference model, which layer is responsible for end-to-end delivery of the entire message?
questions.option2: Data Link Layer

questions.question: What is the main difference between TCP/IP and OSI reference models regarding the number of layers?
questions.option1: TCP/IP has 5 layers, OSI has 7 layers
questions.option2: TCP/IP has 4 layers, OSI has 7 layers
questions.option4: TCP/IP has 6 layers, OSI has 7 layers

questions.question: In Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM), what determines the number of bits that can be transmitted per symbol?
questions.option2: Phase shift interval

questions.question: Which encoding technique is used to convert digital data to digital signals where each bit is represented by two signal elements?
questions.option2: AMI

questions.question: In Pulse Code Modulation (PCM), what is the purpose of the quantization step?
questions.option1: To filter noise from the signal
questions.option2: To convert continuous amplitude values to discrete levels

questions.question: What is the main advantage of single-mode fiber optic cable over multimode fiber?
questions.option2: Lower cost
questions.option4: Higher bandwidth and longer transmission distance

questions.question: In microwave transmission, what causes signal fading?
questions.option2: Insufficient power

questions.question: What is the main difference between packet switching and circuit switching?
questions.option1: Packet switching uses dedicated paths, circuit switching shares paths
questions.option2: Circuit switching is only used for data transmission
questions.option3: Circuit switching establishes dedicated paths, packet switching shares network resources
questions.option4: Packet switching is slower than circuit switching

questions.question: In CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check), what happens when the remainder after division is zero?
questions.option2: No error is detected

questions.question: In Stop-and-Wait ARQ, what happens when an ACK is lost?
questions.option2: The sender immediately sends the next frame
questions.option4: The sender retransmits the frame after timeout

questions.question: What is the main advantage of Selective Repeat ARQ over Go-Back-N ARQ?
questions.option2: Lower memory requirements

questions.question: In CSMA/CD, what does the collision detection mechanism do when a collision is detected?
questions.option2: Send a jam signal and then back off

questions.question: What is the main difference between CSMA/CD and CSMA/CA?
questions.option2: CD is for wireless, CA is for wired networks
questions.option3: CD detects collisions, CA avoids collisions

questions.question: In IEEE 802.5 Token Ring, what happens when a station wants to transmit data?
questions.option2: It broadcasts a request to all stations
questions.option3: It waits for the channel to be idle
questions.option4: It captures the free token and converts it to a data frame

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of Pure ALOHA protocol?
questions.option1: Stations transmit only at specific time slots
questions.option2: Stations can transmit anytime without checking channel status
questions.option4: Stations use carrier sensing before transmission

questions.question: What is the maximum number of hosts possible in a Class B network?
What is the main advantage of IPv6 over IPv4?
questions.option1: Larger address space and built-in IPSec support
questions.option2: Better error correction

questions.question: What is the primary function of a bridge in a network?
questions.option2: Filter and forward frames based on MAC addresses

questions.question: In distance vector routing, what problem does the 'count to infinity' refer to?
questions.option2: Security vulnerabilities

questions.question: What is the main advantage of link state routing over distance vector routing?
questions.option2: Better scalability

questions.question: What type of address does ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) resolve?
questions.option2: Domain name to IP address

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol)?
questions.option2: Error reporting and diagnostic information

questions.question: In IGMP (Internet Group Management Protocol), what is the main function?
questions.option2: Managing unicast routing

questions.question: What is the main difference between UDP and TCP?
questions.option1: UDP is faster but less secure than TCP
questions.option2: TCP uses smaller headers than UDP
questions.option3: UDP is connection-oriented, TCP is connectionless
questions.option4: TCP is connection-oriented and reliable, UDP is connectionless and unreliable

questions.question: In TCP congestion control, what does the slow start algorithm do?
questions.option1: Exponentially increases congestion window until threshold
questions.option2: Maintains constant window size

questions.question: What is the purpose of the TCP three-way handshake?
questions.option2: Establishing a reliable connection

questions.question: In Quality of Service (QoS), what does traffic shaping accomplish?
questions.option2: Increases network bandwidth
questions.option3: Controls the rate of data transmission to smooth traffic flow

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of Integrated Services (IntServ) model?
questions.option2: Best-effort delivery

questions.question: In HTTP, what is the difference between GET and POST methods?
questions.option1: GET retrieves data with parameters in URL, POST sends data in request body
questions.option2: GET uses TCP, POST uses UDP
questions.option3: GET is for downloading, POST is for uploading
questions.option4: GET is secure, POST is not secure

questions.question: What is the main function of DNS (Domain Name System)?
questions.option2: Translate domain names to IP addresses

questions.question: In FTP (File Transfer Protocol), what is the difference between active and passive modes?
questions.option1: Active uses TCP, passive uses UDP
questions.option2: Active is secure, passive is not
questions.option3: In active mode, server initiates data connection; in passive mode, client initiates data connection
questions.option4: Active uses one connection, passive uses two

questions.question: What is the main advantage of peer-to-peer networks over client-server architecture?
questions.option2: Centralized control

questions.question: In SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol), what is the purpose of MIB?
questions.option2: Define the structure of management information

questions.question: What is the main weakness of substitution ciphers?
questions.option1: They can only encrypt small messages
questions.option2: They require too much computational power
questions.option3: They are vulnerable to frequency analysis
questions.option4: They are too complex to implement

questions.question: What is the key size used in the original DES (Data Encryption Standard)?
questions.option2: 256 bits

questions.question: What is the main advantage of public key cryptography over symmetric cryptography?
questions.option2: Uses smaller key sizes

questions.question: In IPSec, what is the difference between tunnel mode and transport mode?
questions.option1: Tunnel mode uses symmetric keys, transport mode uses asymmetric keys
questions.option2: Tunnel mode encapsulates entire IP packet, transport mode only encrypts payload
questions.option3: Tunnel mode is faster than transport mode
questions.option4: Tunnel mode encrypts headers, transport mode doesn't

questions.question: What is the main purpose of TLS/SSL handshake process?
questions.option2: Data compression
questions.option3: Establish secure connection parameters and authenticate parties

questions.question: In VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol), what happens when the master router fails?
questions.option1: The backup router with the highest priority becomes the new master
questions.option2: A new election process begins involving all routers
questions.option3: The network switches to a different protocol
questions.option4: All traffic stops until manual intervention

questions.question: What is the main difference between hub and switch in terms of collision domains?
questions.option2: Hub creates one collision domain, switch creates multiple collision domains
questions.option3: Both create the same number of collision domains
questions.option4: Hub creates multiple collision domains, switch creates one

questions.question: In TCP flow control, what is the purpose of the sliding window mechanism?
questions.option2: Data encryption
questions.option3: Control the amount of data sent without acknowledgment

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of Class D IP addresses?
questions.option2: Used for experimental purposes

questions.question: In wireless LANs, why is CSMA/CA preferred over CSMA/CD?
questions.option2: Collision detection is difficult in wireless medium

questions.question: What is the main function of the Network Access Control Lists (ACLs)?
questions.option2: Error correction
questions.option3: Packet filtering based on predefined rules

questions.question: In Frame Relay, what is the purpose of DLCI (Data Link Connection Identifier)?
questions.option2: Identify virtual circuits on the local interface

questions.question: What is the main advantage of ATM (Asynchronous Transfer Mode) over traditional packet switching?
questions.option2: Lower cost implementation
questions.option4: Fixed-size cells provide predictable delay and bandwidth

questions.question: In MPLS (Multi-Protocol Label Switching), what is the primary benefit of label switching?
questions.option1: Faster packet forwarding and traffic engineering capabilities
questions.option2: Better error correction

questions.question: What is the main purpose of DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)?
questions.option2: Automatic assignment of IP addresses and network configuration

questions.question: In network security, what is the difference between symmetric and asymmetric encryption in terms of key management?
questions.option2: Symmetric is more secure than asymmetric
questions.option3: Symmetric uses same key for encryption/decryption, asymmetric uses different keys
questions.option4: Symmetric uses public keys, asymmetric uses private keys

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of connectionless service at the network layer?
questions.option2: Each packet is treated independently without maintaining connection state
questions.option3: Packets arrive in the same order they were sent

questions.question: Which of the following is a private IPv4 address range?
What is NAT (Network Address Translation) primarily used for?
questions.option2: To translate private IP addresses to public IP addresses

questions.question: Which protocol is used by web browsers to request and display web pages?
questions.option2: SMTP

questions.question: What is the primary role of a firewall in network security?
questions.option2: To prevent unauthorized access to a network

questions.question: Which wireless encryption standard is considered the most secure for Wi-Fi networks today?
questions.option2: WPA

questions.question: What is a subnet mask used for?
questions.option1: To identify the network portion and host portion of an IP address
questions.option2: To assign IP addresses automatically

questions.question: In cellular networks, what is a handoff (or handover)?
questions.option2: Transferring a mobile call from one cell to an adjacent cell

questions.question: What is the purpose of MAC address filtering in a wireless network?
questions.option2: To restrict network access based on physical hardware addresses

questions.question: Which of the following is a broadcast address in IPv4?
What is the function of the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP)?
questions.option1: To prevent routing loops in a network
questions.option2: To ensure loop-free logical topology in Ethernet networks

questions.question: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for data encryption and decryption?
questions.option2: Presentation Layer

questions.question: What is the maximum throughput of a 100BASE-TX Ethernet connection?
questions.option2: 100 Mbps

questions.question: Which component is used to connect different types of networks and translate protocols?
questions.option2: Bridge

questions.question: What is the concept of 'aliasing' in sampling for digital signal processing?
questions.option2: Signal distortion where high-frequency components appear as low-frequency components
questions.option3: Loss of signal strength over distance

questions.question: In cellular communication, what is the role of a Base Transceiver Station (BTS)?
questions.option2: To control call routing between mobile networks
questions.option3: To handle radio communication with mobile phones

questions.question: What is the main function of the 'Time To Live' (TTL) field in an IP packet?
questions.option2: To limit the lifespan of a packet on the network

questions.question: Which of the following is a classless routing protocol?
questions.option2: IGRP

questions.question: What is the primary goal of Network Segmentation?
questions.option2: To isolate network traffic and improve security/performance
questions.option3: To reduce the number of devices on a network

questions.question: In data link layer, what is the purpose of 'framing'?
questions.option2: To encapsulate data into manageable blocks for transmission

questions.question: Which type of multiplexing assigns a dedicated frequency band to each channel?
questions.option2: Frequency Division Multiplexing (FDM)

questions.question: What is a 'man-in-the-middle' attack?
questions.option1: An attack that overloads a server with traffic
questions.option2: An attack where the attacker intercepts and relays communications between two parties
questions.option3: An attack that exploits software vulnerabilities
questions.option4: An attack that steals user credentials

questions.question: What is the purpose of a DNS 'A' record?
questions.option1: Maps a domain name to an IPv6 address
questions.option2: Maps a domain name to an IPv4 address
questions.option4: Defines an alias for a domain name

questions.question: Which error detection method adds a redundant bit to each data unit such that the total number of 1s in the unit is even or odd?
questions.option2: Checksum

questions.question: In cellular networks, what does LTE stand for?
questions.option2: Local Transmission Enhancement

questions.question: What is the primary use of a content delivery network (CDN)?
questions.option2: To distribute content geographically to improve delivery speed and reliability

questions.question: Which switching technique stores the entire frame before forwarding it?
questions.option2: Store-and-forward switching

questions.question: What is a VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network)?
questions.option1: A physical separation of network devices
questions.option2: A logical grouping of network devices that can communicate as if they were on the same physical segment
questions.option4: A dedicated server for network management

questions.question: In wireless communication, what is multipath fading?
questions.option2: Signal variations caused by multiple reflected paths reaching the receiver
questions.option4: Signal degradation due to excessive distance

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'port forwarding' on a router?
questions.option2: To allow external devices to access specific services on devices within a private network
questions.option4: To assign dynamic IP addresses to devices

questions.question: Which protocol is responsible for sending email messages?
questions.option2: IMAP

questions.question: What is the primary function of a Content-Addressable Memory (CAM) in network devices?
questions.option2: To rapidly search for MAC addresses for forwarding decisions

questions.question: In fiber optics, what is the 'cladding' responsible for?
questions.option2: Reflecting light back into the core to prevent signal loss
questions.option3: Protecting the fiber from physical damage

questions.question: What is the main advantage of using a dedicated server for DNS over relying on ISP's DNS servers?
questions.option2: Faster website loading times and more control over DNS records

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a symmetric encryption algorithm?
questions.option2: ECC

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a 'Demilitarized Zone' (DMZ) in network security?
questions.option2: To provide an additional layer of security for services exposed to the public internet

questions.question: In the context of network attacks, what is a 'Smurf attack'?
questions.option1: A type of password cracking attack
questions.option2: A denial-of-service attack that floods a target with ICMP echo requests
questions.option3: An attack that intercepts DNS queries

questions.question: What is the primary difference between a VPN (Virtual Private Network) and a proxy server?
questions.option1: VPN encrypts all network traffic, proxy only specific application traffic
questions.option2: Proxy servers are faster than VPNs
questions.option3: VPNs are only for local networks
questions.option4: Proxy servers offer better security features

questions.question: Which routing protocol uses a metric called 'bandwidth' and 'delay' for path calculation?
questions.option2: EIGRP

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'Digital Signatures' in network security?
questions.option2: To ensure data confidentiality
questions.option3: To verify the authenticity and integrity of a message or document

questions.question: In data communication, what is the 'Nyquist theorem' related to?
questions.option1: Maximum data rate for a noisy channel
questions.option2: Minimum sampling rate required to accurately reconstruct an analog signal

questions.question: What is the primary role of a 'Load Balancer' in a network?
questions.option2: To distribute network traffic across multiple servers to optimize resource utilization and availability

questions.question: In wireless networking, what is 'MIMO' (Multiple-Input, Multiple-Output)?
questions.option2: A technology that uses multiple antennas at both the transmitter and receiver to improve communication performance
questions.option3: A method for extending Wi-Fi range
questions.option4: A type of wireless access point

questions.question: What is the 'three-way handshake' in TCP specifically designed to prevent?
questions.option2: Deadlock scenarios and ensure proper connection establishment

questions.question: Which of the following describes 'PoE' (Power over Ethernet)?
questions.option1: A method to power devices using separate power cables
questions.option2: A technology that allows network cables to carry electrical power
questions.option4: A type of fiber optic connector

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of a 'stateless firewall'?
questions.option1: It remembers the state of active connections
questions.option2: It inspects each packet individually without considering previous packets

questions.question: In network addressing, what is 'CIDR' (Classless Inter-Domain Routing) used for?
questions.option1: To divide a network into smaller subnets
questions.option2: To enable more efficient use of IP addresses and route aggregation

questions.question: What is the primary function of a 'honeypot' in network security?
questions.option2: To attract and trap attackers to gather information about their methods
questions.option3: To scan for vulnerabilities in a network

questions.question: Which type of network topology is most resilient to single-point failures?
questions.option2: Star topology

questions.question: What is the main concept behind 'Software-Defined Networking' (SDN)?
questions.option1: Centralizing network control and abstracting the underlying infrastructure
questions.option2: Using only open-source networking equipment
questions.option3: Eliminating the need for network administrators

questions.question: In network performance, what is 'jitter'?
questions.option1: The loss of data packets during transmission
questions.option2: The variation in the delay of received packets
questions.option3: The maximum data rate of a network
questions.option4: The time it takes for a packet to travel from source to destination
